column1: Coeliac disease is caused by an autoimmune reaction to gluten. Is this true or false?
column8: True. Coeliac disease is a disease of the small intestine in which damage to the lining of the small intestine leads to malabsorption of minerals and nutrients. The destruction of the inner lining of the small intestine in celiac disease is caused by an immunological reaction to gluten, a family of proteins found in wheat, barley, rye, and oats.

column1: A reaction to ingesting milk may be the result of?
column8: Correct C. A reaction to milk products can be either the result of a milk allergy, or the result of lactose intolerance and problems with the digestive system.

column1: What causes the symptoms related to food intolerance?
column8: Correct B. Highly processed grains, such as cereals, can be difficult to digest, leading to symptoms of food intolerance. Similarly, the processing of milk and/or soy products can be difficult to digest, leading to food intolerance symptoms.

column1: What are the typical foods that produce food intolerance?
column8: Correct A. Dairy and gluten-containing grains, such as wheat, rye, barley, oats and spelt, are the most common food intolerance culprits.
